datafield.subfield: p. 25 (b. Elizabeth Heaphy in London, 1815) p. 29 (became member of the Institute of Painters in Water-colour) p. 30 (d. Dec. 8, 1882, San Remo)
Sixteen years of an artist's life in Morocco, Spain, and the Canary Islands, 1859:
NUCMC data from Maine Hist. Soc. for Elizabeth Heaphy Murray research collection, 1977-2012

(Elizabeth Heaphy Murray (1815-1882) was an English water-color painter in the 19th century. The daughter of Thomas Heaphy, court painter to King George IV, Murray founded the Society of Female Artists in London. From 1860 to 1876 she resided in Portland, Me., where her husband, Henry Murray, served as the British Consul. It was in Portland that she gained notoriety and penning a book on painting titled "The Modern System of Painting in Water Colours from the Living Model." Her work has been noted among that of the 19th century's most influential female painters. In an 1863 letter to the editor of the Daily Press (of Portland, Me.) touting the presence of Elizabeth Heaphy Murray in Portland, Murray is referred to as "one of the most gifted artists of the age.")
